It is impossible to do a project.  You can only do a series of specific actions that will advance the project toward its goals.   Procrastination is typically a result of the indecision that results from the overwhelming number of choices for what to do.
You break this deadlock by decomposing a large project into a series of smaller projects.  This about your project as an outline of projects.  At each level completing the project is a matter of completing each of the projects underneath of it.
The project plan is nothing more than the mapping of the projects into sub-projects.  Two important questions emerge: How many sub-projects should be under each of the projects?  How deep should the planning process go?
The value of any list decreases with the length.  A flat list of the hundred things that you need to do has little value and will overwhelm you.   A good rule of thumb is to start with three things that must be done and allow it to grow as the problem dictates.  
Don't use any more than seven projects under one project. Use nesting to capture the additional detail. This will also force you to balance the sub-projects relative to each other.  For example, when writing a book you would not plan it out as "Think about title", "Write and publish all content".  Pick sub-projects that are roughly equal is size and scope.
The depth that you do when planning is an important choice that you make.  Choose a depth that allows you to accurately see the scope of your project.  Use past experience to determine how to breakdown the first few levels.  The planning that you do now will set how you will track progress during the project.  But at this point in the project, you don't need to plan out all of the details.
Once you have created the initial task breakdown it is time to begin doing the work that you have outlined.  Start by taking the first lowest-level task in your outline. Estimate how long this will take.  If this task will take longer than a day then repeat the simple planning steps to decompose only this task into a smaller set of tasks (each of which require no more than one day to complete).
This planning method gives you lots of detail for things that are very close while retaining flexibility for future changes in the project.  It provides you with a very simple and robust plan for getting all the way from the start of the project to the end goals.
fields.title: Breakdown tasks

fields.body:
Your project plan allows you to directly measure the rate of your progress.  From the first day of the project you will be able to estimate how you are doing relative to how you thought you were doing.
Avoid the temptation to predict the future.  Trust in the measure of the progress already made, not in the hope that you will be able to make up lost time.  This tracking is based upon the reality of actual performance rather than the desired outcome.  Therefore, it can not be corrupted by pressure to tell a different story.  
The best way to bring in a project that will be late is to reduce its scope or add more resources to the project. Both of these changes to the project plan must be done early enough in the project to affect the outcome. This planning method makes it clear that changing the plan late in a project only makes it later.
During the project you can never back up and do it over.   All you can do is lay out the best possible plan from this point to the project completion.  You can never affect the past, but you must control the future.  Measuring progress throughout the project is the single most important practice you can do.
fields.title: Measure progress

fields.body:
Things change.  Then they change some more.  Change is constant.  You need planning methods that recognize this.  Large projects need even more flexibility, while maintaining the ability to coordinate all of the different dependencies.

You should review your plans weekly to keep them fresh.  If you need to coordinate between multiple people, departments, and companies, then the best way to do this is to identify key deliverables.  Each deliverable represents work that one group needs to provide to another group on a certain date to keep the project on track.

These dates should not move around much since this can cause a great deal of pain.   Constantly be watching the key deliverables and estimating the likelihood of keeping that commitment.  For those items that are in jeopardy assess the impact that a late delivery will have on the overall project.  Figure out mitigation plans when they are required.

Don't hide in denial.  When a part of the project threatens the whole, figure out how you can lessen the impact of this failure.   Don't let one domino knock over all of the rest.  Don't let one thread unravel the entire sweater.  

Fix the issue and move consistently to the goal.  Make a new plan, Stan.  Remember, the planning is much more important than the plan.  Always recognize reality.   Hope is not a valid planning method.
fields.title: Review and adapt

fields.body: Windows is the most popular operating system in use today.   The following articles will give you ways to be more effective as you use Windows.  These tips are intended to be easy to setup and use.  You will be able to try out each of these ideas within a few minutes to see if they work for you.
fields.title: Microsoft Windows Tips

fields.body:
It is time for an honest self-assessment. Many organizations that I work with continue to struggle with one major problem. “How can we communicate more effectively?” This question resonates throughout businesses and non-profit organizations.

This issue of communication can be broken into vision, audience, message, tools, and process. A simple self-assessment can be conducted in a few minutes by asking three questions in each of these key areas. This is a very straightforward process that anyone can do. However, very few organizations that I work with have ever really asked themselves these questions.

By answering these questions you will be far ahead of most organizations. You will be aware of communication issues that exist all around you. This will enable you to begin developing a systematic approach to communicate the important details that others need to know.
fields.title: How Effective is Your Communication?

fields.body:
Each person has their own style of communication.  We also have our own preference for the methods of communication.  Some people prefer face-to-face interactions while other prefer phone calls, emails, or group meetings.   It is important to understand the preferred methods of the people that you work most closely with.  You may not always be able to accommodate their preferences.  But knowing what works for them will allow you to select the most effective method for each interaction.

People typically know what types of communications work for them. You can simple ask each person that you work with closely what type of communication works most effectively with them.
fields.title: Preferred communication channels

fields.body:
Self-leadership

It is impossible to be good at leading others without first mastering yourself. This is not always an easy thing to do but it is necessary. It is hard to inspire and motivate others if we can’t even inspire ourselves. This can sometimes take some energy, but it is well worth the effort.

John C. Maxwell wrote an excellent book on this subject, entitled “Today Matters”. In this book he describes the effects of the commitments that we make in a number of different areas. Each commitment that we make is established or undermined by our daily habits. Once the emotion that produced the commitment fades, we are left with these daily habits to carry us through.

There are twelve areas in which we make commitments that need to be serviced daily. These are what Maxwell calls the Daily Dozen. They include:

* Attitude: Choose and display the right attitude.

* Priority: Determine and act on important priorities.

* Health: Know and follow healthy guidelines.

* Family: Communicate and care for my family.

* Thinking: Practice and develop good thinking.

* Commitment: Make and keep proper commitments.

* Finances: Make and properly manage money.

* Faith: Deepen and live out my faith.

* Relationships: Initiate and invest in solid relationships.

* Generosity: Plan for and model generosity.

* Values: Embrace and practice good values.

* Growth: Seek and experience improvements.

Self-leadership involves all of these unique aspects. As we seek to be better leaders, we should start with ourselves. To be able to motivate and influence others, we must first work on our own daily habits. Sometimes this is the most difficult step in leadership.

Take a few minutes and score yourself against these personal commitments. How do you fare? Where would you like to grow?
fields.title: Self Leadership

fields.body:
I once heard a business coach, Nigel Clayton, give some great counsel:  Imagine that someone is writing a newspaper about your life and business.  What would the headlines look like?  Would it be interesting to read?  Every day you should do something worthy of headlines.  These are the things that have strategic importance to your life and your business.  Tactical things must also be done each day, but these have limited impact and are quickly forgotten.

Strategic decisions are those that have far-reaching consequences.  Each day you should be able to identify at least one decision that you made that will affect your life a year from now.  If nothing comes to mind, maybe you have been too focused on the tactical and not enough on the strategic.  It is so easy to get caught up in the day-to-day turmoil that we forget to look at the bigger picture.

It is extremely easy to incorporate the practice of creating daily headlines into your life.  Most of us have a few minutes of planning time in the morning as we start our day.  Simply pause to ask the question, “What did I do yesterday for my headline?”  This will quickly bring you to the most important thing that you did of lasting value.

The logical extension of asking what you did, is to ask what you are planning to do today that will be remembered. This practice does not take much time, but it does create an opportunity for introspection and adjustment.  I would challenge you to try this simple exercise for two weeks to see what impact it has for you.  Write me and tell me your story.
fields.title: Write headlines every day

fields.body:
Many people think of leaders as those with official leadership positions. While it is true that people with positions of authority are almost always leaders, it is also possible to demonstrate leadership without a title. Leadership is primarily about influence, and you can be a person of influence wherever you are.

People in positions of authority have a special need to influence others. Trust is the most important ingredient in creating influence. Leaders who have not gained the trust of others will lack influence and will exhibit poor leadership. Remember, people will always follow someone they trust.

Trust is earned over a period of time, and it is impossible to force someone to trust you. As a result, influence cannot be extracted merely by holding a position of authority. Therefore, leadership is something that a person grows into by making decisions that are beneficial to others.

Once others realize that you truly desire to help them, you will have influence in their lives. There is no shortcut to influence. You may be able to force obedience for a while, but you cannot force influence.

As we begin to understand that leadership is tied to influence we realize that anyone can lead. The true leaders in any group are the ones that people listen to and follow. This is not always the person at the top of the hierarchy.

Positional authority is typically awarded to recognize increased leadership. The position recognizes, but does not create, leadership. In most cases, leadership is learned and earned.

You can begin acting today in a way that demonstrates to others that you care for their welfare. This will definitely result in an increase of your leadership ability.
fields.title: What Makes A Leader?

fields.body:
We all want to make a difference. We each want to do something of lasting value. Every one of us would like to help others improve their lives in some way. Otherwise, we would stay in bed all day and watch old TV reruns.

But this burning desire to produce value often leaves people feeling frustrated. They want to benefit others but don't seem to find the opportunities that they need to do so. This is where you, as a leader, can step in and help them. You can define ways for people to contribute to some purpose that is beyond themselves.

In fact, the process of defining opportunities for others will lead you on a personal journey of your own. By looking for ways to “give back” to your community, you will become aware of opportunities that have been missing for years.

There is something extremely beneficial and fulfilling about trying to help others. It gives purpose and meaning to everything that we do. This is an area that represents a significant part of each of our lives. People that can not see beyond their own needs become increasingly in-grown and self-centered. It is also difficult for these people to have any sort of meaningful relationships.

Some leaders are already committed to so many projects and causes that gathering more commitments would be harmful rather than beneficial. If you are one of these leaders, I encourage you to begin thinking about how you can get others excited about helping you. Instead of increasing your commitment level you can try to increase the commitment of others you know.

Can you think of a project that you are involved in currently? Are there too few people to help and too much work to accomplish? Who do you know that could benefit from this opportunity to serve? Select people who are under-committed today. Don't choose the overworked rowers that are already in your boat.

Think about this new opportunity from the perspective of the potential server. Is it a good opportunity for them? Do they bring strengths and passions that are well suited to the project? If so, then this is a project that could be very meaningful to them. Don't be apologetic about asking for their help. If you are trying to help yourself you probably should not ask. But if you truly believe this is an opportunity that will enhance their life then go for it.
fields.title: Make a Difference

fields.body:
We are surrounded by great books.  There is currently enough information available that every man, woman, and child has 16 feet of book shelf space that is completely unique to them.  In other words, there is far more information created than will ever be read by anyone.

In this environment it is critical to become a master at selection.  How do you select the information that will make your life better, from all of the other information that is available?

I recommend the 'pass it on' test.  When I read I pretend to be an agent for my dopple-ganger in a parallel universe.  This person is interested in the exact same subjects that I am but may not be exposed to the same media.

Some information is worth passing on, but much is not.   When you find a gem add it to your reading list.  If you find a great blog book mark it.  If you discover a book that gives you key insights then put it on a list.

Next, find other sources of information that are connected to what you found interesting.  Does this book or blog reference others?  Are there a group of people that always write about interesting things?  

Information is connected together in pools.   Once you find a repository that you like then you have discovered and source of future enjoyment.  A author that you enjoy is very likely to produce other works that you will also enjoy.  This is something that you must exploit to maximize your learning.

The flip side of this is also true.  Avoid information that does not ring your bell.  Use the 'three strikes' rule to eliminate items from your diet that don't give you what you want?  Life is too short to waste it reading garbage.
fields.title: Read

fields.body:
Since the time I was a child I have been interested in technology. I have always been fascinated with the way things work. My parents were not always pleased when my curiosity drove me to take things apart to figure out how they worked. Over time though, this has developed into an adult-level understanding of invention and productivity. These natural tendencies are now coupled with experience and allow me to apply my energy to helping other people with technology.

In college I studied electrical engineering and graduated at the top of my class in 1981. After graduation I took a job with Hewlett-Packard and began designing disk drive controllers. My first project was a gigantic, 400 MB disk drive the size of a washing machine. During the course of my 25 years at HP I had the opportunity to design parts of many wonderful products, including: scanners, OCR software, web sites, printers, and digital cameras. One of the greatest joys for me is to walk into a store that carries consumer electronics and see all of the many products that I contributed to.

In 2007 I followed my dream and started a company, called Shrinking World Solutions. This company would serve the needs of businesses and non-profit organizations. Over the years I have had a lot of interactions with small business owners and non-profit leaders. Almost universally I see the same issues in play. Small organizations desperately need to utilize technology. However, it is bewildering to the leaders. How do we set it up? How do we keep it running? What if it doesn’t do what was promised? These concerns are so daunting that most leaders try to ignore technical solutions until they have a crisis.

In the last five years, we have seen a remarkable transformation in the high-tech industry. The internet has become the focal point for virtually all software. This allows people with nothing more than an internet connection to operate on a level playing field. Large companies with dedicated IT departments become very similar to a small business that relies on remote software to operate.

The world has truly become a small place. Small businesses can now sell products and services globally. The internet opens a new world of possibilities for businesses and organizations. Now it is no longer necessary to expend large amounts of capital to reach a global audience. This shrinking world phenomenon is at the doorstep of every small business and non-profit organization.

Shrinking World Solutions empowers you to reach the world, by offering low-cost technology and training on how to get the most from it. I believe in using low-cost tools that already exist, but also have the capability to produce new solutions when needed. Solutions don’t have to be complicated to meet the challenge either; you just have to know how things really work first.
fields.title: A drive to invent

fields.body:
Effective and strategic communication should be done intentionally. A communication system can be developed as any other system. With this in mind, there are 10 objectives for strategic communication.

   1. Everyone hears the same thing.
   2. People receive information in a form they can digest.
   3. The technology delivers messages automatically.
   4. The message is designed to advance trust and commitment.
   5. All messages have objectives.
   6. Results are measured consistently.
   7. Web sites are used for “pulling” information and email for “pushing” it.
   8. Format is a compelling part of the message.
   9. Private communication is used to refine public communication.
  10. Incremental improvement is a constant process.
fields.title: Ten rules for communication

fields.body:
One of the most intriguing books I have read in a while is by Tim Ferris, called the "4-hour Work Week".  It covers to the topic of not just working less, but more importantly getting a lot more from life.  The fundamental premise of the book is that with can achieve greater results and work less.  This is a result of focusing on the few things that actually produce the best results for us.

He outlines specific tactics for how to eliminate the waste that takes over most of our days.  After we have pruned off all but the essential tasks then it is time to automate.  This allows the remaining tasks to be completed with the smallest amount of time invested from us.

We then use this newfound productivity to create new goals that are based on life dreams.  For Tim a lot of these goals involve travel.  He uses the flexibility of being about to work from anywhere in the world to create a lifestyle where he does.

As you read the "4-hour Work Week" you will stumble upon some real insights that will change how you percieve your work life.  This will cause you to change part of how you do work.  The book must be filtered into your work context rather than applied directly.  But this effort will certainly pay off for you.
fields.title: 4-hour Work Week

fields.body: This article discusses how to build a knowledge system that is a critical business asset. Many companies have a need to build a system to capture the important information that is used to run the daily aspects of the business. There are many obstacles to creating a system like this. Without giving careful thought to these barriers these project is likely to spend a great deal of money without ever achieving the desired benefit. Each of the keys discussed here will increase the effectiveness of the system that is created. If all of these aspects are well designed then the system is certain to exceed the goals set for it.
fields.title: Keys to Building a Successful Knowledge System

fields.body: There is a lot of opportunity for those who wish to do good.  These articles explore the dynamics of helping others.  There are a number of different challenges that we face as we try to make that world a better place.  Hopefully, you will get some ideas that you can use from these discussions.
fields.title: Doing good

fields.body:
Probably the most important aspect of leadership is giving people a reason to push forward.  Everyone will lose motivation at one point or another.  The job of a leader is to help each person understand that their contribution is vital and appreciated.  

Leaders typically ask people to make sacrifices.  In return, there must be a reward.  Asking someone to make a sacrifice with no perceived benefit is simply foolish.  

Keep in mind that the benefits, need not be monetary.  In fact the most important rewards are never about money.  Leaders must become creative in understanding the people they are leading and providing the things that they most value.

These can be as intangible as a future opportunity or recognition for a job well done.  They may also be concrete rewards like a time off or a bonus.  Think about creative ways to meet the needs of the people on your team.
fields.title: Motivation

fields.body:
Create a vision in the minds of the team that you lead.  Help each person understand the end-goal that you wish to achieve and why it is critical.  If the vision that you share is not utterly compelling to you then it will not be embraced by your team.

Work on ways to describe the vision.   Many leaders spend too much time on trying to "word smith" the vision statement rather than develop the substance of the vision itself.  Describe your vision to everyone that you come in contact with.  If you struggle with how to share it with others then it needs more work.   If people don't resonate with with the idea then continue to develop the vision until you can easily get the response that you are looking for.

A compelling vision should resonate with others.  Even if they are not the ones that will help you realize the vision they should be able to understand your passion and the values moving you forward.
fields.title: Vision

fields.body:
Most books have a few good ideas to offer.  I read a lot and almost every book has some kind of impact on my thinking.  The books on this list are in an entirely different class.  They are packed full of great ideas that cause a fundamental shift in thinking.  The application is immediate and comprehensive.  They contain ideas that shift your paradigms.

I recommend that you read each of these books, study them, and get your friends to discuss the material with you.
fields.title: Books that shaped my life

fields.body:
People who travel have a broader perspective than those that do not.  Travel has a lot of interesting benefits.  It also has a fairly high cost, so it cannot be undertaken lightly.  Consider how your learning experiences can be augmented with travel.

There is something amazing about going to somewhere that you have read about for years.  You are able to verify assumptions and interact with people that can tell first-hand stories about thier experiences.  Being is a place is so real and viceral compared to simply reading about something or watching the video.

When you travel you have your own stories.  Things happen that are frustrating, exhilarating, and scary.  It is these times that cause you to grow personally.  These are not things that you seek out, but if you travel much you will get some travel stories to tell.

Overcoming the obstacles that you encounter is actually one of the main benefits of travel.  After surviving several travel ordeals you learn to become adaptible.  This flexible is a great benefit to you in other situations that you are likely to encounter.

Another major benefit of travel is that you gain a greater awareness of culture.  By seeing someone else's culture first hand you learn to make observations about your own culture.  For example, after being in Europe, I am aware of how hurried Americans are when we eat.  If all I were ever to experience is fast food dining, then it would not be obvious how unusual that is.

It is impossible to travel without confronting prejudice.  Both your own judgements about others and their judgements toward use surface when keep assumptions are challenged.  People that never travel can carefully protect their own illusions of reality, but these are dispelled when you come face-to-face with people that live in another reality.

The other major benefit of travel is that it is intellectually stimulating.  Anywhere you go is a change in context.  You are likely to get new ideas.  The farther you go the bigger the adventure.  You will see new places, eat new foods, hear new languages, experience new bathroom facilities, and meet new people.

You will love it and you will hate it.  But you will be truly alive.

Traveling to other places breaks our daily habits and routines.  This can open our eyes to new people and places if we allow it.  We can become aware of new cultures and people that are not "just like us".  People that travel are typically much more open than those who do not.
fields.title: Travel

fields.body:
* Create a wiki for project communication

* Develop and collaborate with clients on project plan

* Develop weekly iteration plan (show running stuff every week)

* Develop method for getting feedback

* Train workers on using the project wiki and project tools
fields.title: Project Planning

fields.body:
* Use wiki daily for project communication with workers (what did I do?, what am I doing?, what are the challenges?)

* Use IM for instant interaction and task coordination

* Create work cycle around the weekly client meeting (show result, get direction, highlight issues)

* Always have work viewable by client

* Fix defects before adding new functionality

* Perform tasks in iterations
fields.title: Project Execution

fields.body:
* Get confirmation of completed work

* Confirm terms of ongoing support

* Complete payment of workers
fields.title: Project completion

fields.body:
Humans are naturally curious.  Allow yourself to pursue your inquisitive side.  Ask yourself, "Why?"

There is a reason for everything.  If you hope to make lasting change you must undertand why things are that way.  It is too easy to change a symptom without addressing the underlying cause.  This will inevitably fail and potentially create an even worse situation.

Nothing preserves the status quo more than a failed attempt at change.  "Oh, we tried that and look where it got us", is the sure sign that that change was applied without understanding the real cause.  Don't pick the leaves, go for the roots.

After identifying your primary pain it is time to explore causes.  The initial problem that you selected is probably too large.  You may need to drill down at least one level to find something that you can successfully change.

Every opportunity can be broken into smaller ones.  Identify areas that you wish to change and ask, "Why is it this way currently?"  Repeat this process until you reach a level where you think you can solve the problem.

    Dig deeper!    It is vital to thoroughly understand why things are a certain way. To do this we can take our main problem and find reasons why it is that way. This will typically yield several different causes. For example, poor customer satisfaction can be caused by poor quality, missed deliveries, or bad support experiences.

    One of these causes may dominate. If you hope to move the primary issue, invest in changing the issues that are most responsible for the cause. This get you one step closer to the root issue.

    To get deeper is to repeat the practice of asking "Why?". Process experts recommend asking "Why?" five times before being satisfied that you have found the correct issue to fix. In other words, you may need to drill down on a problem five times in order to get to the root source that causes it.

    If you are prepared to invest in analyzing a problem in this way your likelihood of solving greatly it increases. As an incentive think about the impact of truly solving a huge problem that you have been wrestling with. How much is this solution worth to your organization? How much time and money should you invest in order to fix it. Here's a hint. Only work on problems that have at least five times the payback (considering investment/benefit).
fields.title: Investigate

fields.body:
You can become more significantly productive by learning to become a master delegator. Delegation gives you the leverage to focus on your superpower while still accomplishing many tasks that are outside of it. Using others to complete activities that are not part of your core strengths lets you concentrate on your areas of brilliance. However, delegation can be tricky. It's not complex, but it may be hard to figure out how to make it work well.

I recommend setting up delegation as three components: selecting tasks, setting expectations, and verifying the results. Every task worth delegating is worth setting up in this way. You should consciously think through each of these elements or just do the task yourself.

Not every task should be delegated. They should be carefully selected using the following criteria:

1. Does delegating this task save me significant time? If not don't delegate.

2. Is the goal clear enough to communicate efficiently? If not then you may have to do so much communication and redirection that it loses the benefit you were hoping to achieve.

3. Will you repeat this task many times? You get the biggest benefits from delegating tasks that can be taught once and repeated many times without having to do additional training. Think about the one-time setup costs and the setup costs associated with repeating the task.

Once you have selected the task it is time to set expectations. Start by deciding the objectives that you have for the task. What will the completed result be like? How long will it take? What are the keys for success? How much should it cost? How will you verify and incorporate the results?

These expectations must be written down and given to the person that is to carry out the task. Unspoken expectations are road to disappointment. Special care should be given to new tasks that you have not done before.

Before you can communicate expectations clearly, you should consider performing the tasks three times yourself. The first time allows you to decide what you are really looking for. The second time lets you write down a pattern that can be followed by another person about the steps that they should follow to achieve the desired results. The third time allows you to verify that the pattern actually works. This written pattern is the simplest form of training and will save you a lot of time in discussions with the person doing the work.

The third aspect of delegation is verifying that the results are acceptable and incorporating them into your organization. This involves acceptance testing and integration. If you have done a good job of setting the expectations then you already have a list of the acceptance criteria. This can be used as a check list to ensure that all of the desired elements are in place. The results of the delegated task do not produce a benefit until they have been combined with other task to produce the desired business result. When delegating, make sure to plan for how you will benefit from the work that is done.
fields.title: Secrets of delegation

fields.body:
Here is an outline of a simple set of practices that you can use to manage almost any project. The objective of this process is to have a predictable system for managing projects that sets clear expectations, provide real-time progress updates throughout the project, provides early warning of issues, uses just enough process to keep things running smoothly.

The process involves several stages and for each stage there are some keys to success that you should follow.
fields.title: Project management

fields.body:
We live in an exciting time of rapid technological advancement. Every month new products change the landscape of what is possible and what is practical. Shrinking-world.org tracks these changes and can help you spot emerging trends.

    Shrinking World Guides provide you with tips for how to thrive in the modern world.

    The focus of these articles is applying technologies to simplify your life. Some small changes will make things a lot easier for you. Here you will find pointers that help you use technology to solve real-world problems.

    Shrinking World Guide is a web site, and online book dedicated to Technology, Personal Effectiveness, and Leadership. These important topics are interesting in their own right, but they are also synergistic.

    You can also save this entire content for off-line reading. Just select 'Entire Book' from the top of the page to get the whole book as a single web page. You can save this page and later read it without being connected to the internet.

    The content is organized as a series of three major topics. The Technology part covers emerging technology that is likely to affect your everyday life. Personal Effectiveness deals with getting things done in a way that maximizes your overall enjoyment in life. Leadership helps you understand your role in influencing others.
fields.title: Introduction

fields.body:
Create a personal dashboard!  When you arrive at work and turn on your computer you need to see a dashboard which tells you how things are going and what you should work on next. Unfortunately many of us have a large collection of dashboards with no meaningful integration between them.

I've been exploring this idea as part of creating a personal productivity platform. When I get ready to work, I type "dashbd" and magic happens on my computer. A text editor is run with my work agenda, accomplishments, projects, and future projects. A browser is run with all of my web-based applications. This includes email, task list, calendar, and twitter.

Everything is laid out in front of me to provide a great starting point. By running two actual applications (each with four or five tabs of information), all of my information is readily accessible with a single click.

Most people spend an enormous amount of time just clicking around through files trying to find content  that will get the next task started. Consider creating your own personal dashboard that holds all of your indispensable information.
fields.title: Your Information System

fields.body:
How does your business function? What activities do you perform each day that make you successful? These are most likely the systems in your business? Any well-run organization has documented systems that define how things are done. Without taking the step of writing down these recipes, you must rely on the knowledge of the specific individuals that do the required jobs. What if that person is not a work? Do you want you business to stop?

It is easy to train a new employee on a system that is documented. This let's you cross-train more people and captures the critical aspects of doing a particular job. This information will provide a consistency in how tasks are done. No longer does each new repetition need to be a first time learning experience. Employees can learn the best practice from those that are doing the job best.

Once a process has been documented then you have defined a standard operating procedure. Now you can look at this to see if it can be improved. Once the four-minute mile became the new benchmark many runners began to look at this as the time to beat (not an impossible barrier). You can capture your current business practices and then try to develop and evolve them to something that continues to serve you better and better.

If you go to the trouble of developing system documentation how long should it be? I try to document everything critical about a system on a single page. Write the document but keep it short. Systems are naturally nested in each other so break a complicated system in subsystems, and further into more subsystems.

Anyone can write a page of documentation to tell someone how something works. This will become the foundation that you will build all of your business practices on. Keep it short but get it done. You will be glad you did it.
fields.title: Documenting Systems

fields.body:
Finding an online community to join is sometimes difficult.  With the explosion of the internet and the proliferation of discussion forums, blogs, webinars, and groups, it can be very confusing. There are probably groups out there that are discussing exactly what you need to know, but where do you start?

I would recommend that you start reading one or two blogs (web logs) that are related to your interests.  Blogs are quickly becoming one of the main ways for content to be published on the internet.  There is a great tool for searching through blogs at http://technorati.com.
Technorati is your gateway to the world of blogging.  From here you will be able to search for content you care about throughout the “blogosphere”.  You will also be able to see the most popular blogs on the internet (by number of readers).

Often, bloggers are tied into other forms of online community.  Once you find a blog you like, you can see other related web sites and online communities either in the overview for the blog or in the content itself.  If you are still looking for other connections to this content, then send email to the blogger and ask for advice.


People online can be extremely helpful.  There are certainly miscreants out there creating viruses and spam, but most people are eager to provide useful information.  The internet is a worldwide intellectual commons where someone able to navigate its highways and byways can easily access millions of other people.

The intent of Shrinking World Online (located at http://shrinking-world.org) is to give people a place to interact with others on the topics of Technology, Business, Leadership, and Community.  We believe that people working together can do so much more than they can individually.  A community is built around this goal of mutual benefit.

    Learn from Others!   The internet is a phenomenal place to learn. There are so many interesting sources of information. Never before has so much data been so close to so many. Yet, at the same time, it can be hard to find things. It can also be hard to connect with others.

    A community provides a social connection with other people that share your interests. It sets you on a path that will cause that interest to grow in a certain direction. For example, if you are interested in creating websites, joining a website design group will cause you to learn things that you did not specifically set out to learn.

    The power of an online community is much like the benefit of belonging to a community “in the real world”. We share experiences, hopes, dreams and fears with one another. In doing so, we learn at a faster level and have a richer journey along the way.

    If you are hoping to grow in some area, find an online community that will help you. The benefit of the internet is that your community can be composed of people all over the world. While you may have a hard time finding someone with your interest locally, there may be thousands elsewhere.

    If your interest is Technology, Business, Leadership, or Community then you can find kindred spirits at http://shrinking-world.org. This is an online community dedicated to discussing those topics. We hope to see you there.
fields.title: Finding a Community

fields.body:
What I'm about to say is incredibly obvious to some of you and relatively obscure to others: WE NEED OTHER PEOPLE.

Some people are naturally wired to connect with others; they make friends quickly and can always find common ground. For others, forming relationships is a big challenge. No matter which camp we find ourselves in, we need the input and insight that other people have to offer.

It can be easy for us to fool ourselves into thinking that we have a great idea, but once we air the idea in public we may find that it still needs more development. This is because other people are able to see ideas from a different perspective due to their background. Ideas are best developed and polished through the interactions of the different viewpoints that we each bring.

Every great idea can be made better by sharing it with others. All of us need to find a safe place to interact with others for the purpose of developing ideas and solving problems.

Many people are reluctant to share their best ideas with others. They falsely believe that it is safer to keep their ideas to themselves.  It is true that you should be careful about how and when you share an idea.   However, an idea that is never shared is one that is never tested and probably will never be developed.  When an idea is shared it often turns into a new and more powerful idea.  So instead of losing the original idea a new one has been given birthorn.

When we are trying to solve problems it is often useful to get the input of others.  We can all benefit by the experience of others.  Most problems we encounter have been confronted and solved by someone else.  It is good to have a community of people that can help us find solutions that we are looking for.  These are proven techniques that they have used and found to be effective.

We are in the process of creating such a community online. It is based on the idea that people want to help each other succeed.  In future articles I will be providing more information about this online community and how you can become a part of it.
fields.title: The Value Of Others

fields.body:
One of the most amazing things has happened over the last few years, the Open Source movement has completely changed the nature of software engineering, the high-tech industry, and our society in general. Open Source software is created by teams of people working for free. Yes, you read right. People from different companies, nations, and professions willingly work together to create high-quality software. This software is then distributed and supported free of charge.
I first came across Open Source software in the mid-eighties. Richard Stallman created an organization called the “Free Software Foundation”. This team published a manifesto that was based on the idea that software should be owned by everyone, and that it was immoral for companies to hoard this value to themselves. While Sallman was pretty extreme in his views, he created a movement that was to change the world.

Much of the explosive growth in the internet was caused by the availability of free software. Without it, innovation would be much more expensive and the higher development costs would make all software many times more expensive than what we see today. This would seriously curtail the new applications that anyone can use today.

Today you can get high-quality tools in every possible category, including all of the most important office applications (including word processors, spreadsheets, presentations, databases, graphics editors, operating systems, and email). These applications are the lifeblood of any business. You cannot run a business without them, and the Open Source versions rival the commercial versions in every category.

I have outfitted my business, Shrinking World Solutions, using Open Source software. To set up a new computer in our company we install a stack of about 20 applications. These are all free and give everyone in the company the exact same tools and configuration. This software configuration would cost around $5,000 per computer, but with cheap hardware, we can set up a new computer for $300 and two hours of time.
fields.title: Open Source

fields.body:
Amazing things can happen when we change the way that we look at the world. Many people see through a lens of “Scarcity”. This produces a feeling that there is a limited amount of resources that must be shared by everyone. If someone else gets a bigger piece of the pie, I will get a smaller one.  This attitude is based upon the assumption of fixed resources.

What if the resources were not fixed but unlimited? How would that affect our perception? When we see the world through a lens of “Abundance”, we open ourselves to the opportunities that surround us. If we believe that the pie is of an adjustable size, then we begin to explore how we can make the pie bigger. If we are able to enlarge the pie, we all benefit.

Every business and organization competes in some way for customers, members, or awareness. This is often viewed as a competition for fixed resources: “If I get more someone else must get less.” Many of these situations, however, allow us to find opportunities that allow everyone to come out better. This attitude of abundance allows us to pursue cooperation over competition.

Is your organization really at odds with every other organization in the world, or are there ways that you share common goals and interests with others? Try to identify these common points of connection and find ways to establish alliances that let you both succeed. Two organizations that are aligned on a common goal can be much more effective than both of them working independently.

A word of caution must be added to this message: the relationship will work well only if you are in agreement about the goal. If you do not have agreement on the desired outcome, the coordination may fail. You may find yourselves working at cross-purposes.

You must also be careful to allow time for the relationship to develop. Do not expect marriage on the first date. Select a project of mutual interest and see how that develops before making a larger commitment to each other.

My experience working with many organizations over the years is that not enough of them think about how to work with others. Most people are so consumed with their own challenges that they are blinded to some great opportunities around them.

Take a few minutes and think about the best opportunity that you have to work with someone in another organization. What is the common goal? What would you get out of the deal? What would they get? Is it worth the effort?
fields.title: Competitors become partners

fields.body:
A wavent is a virtual occurrence where multiple people gather online, simultaneously to author a Google Wave. The topic is hosted by a Wavent Coordinator whose job is to define the topic and the time. At the requested time the Wavent Coordinator will create the initial wave which introduces the topic.

During the actual Wavent participants are encouraged to make the maximum contribution to the online discussion. Google Wave is a perfect tool for this interactive discussion and collaboration. Consider the wavent to be an intellectual and communication feeding frenzy that lasts for a couple of hours.

After the wavent the wave can be referenced by others and updated as participants desire. This is a great way to use crowd-sourcing to create a written record on a significant subject. It can be a way to produce a web site with real content in two hours.

Wavents work best when there is a group of experts that desire to interact on a specific topic. A few simple rules of etiquette are required to keep the wavent on track.

The concept of open space gives wavents three expectations:

1. Those who participate are the right people.

2. Whatever happens is the only thing that could have happened.

3. Participate as long as you are contributing or learning.
fields.title: Google Wave Event

fields.body:
To earn a place as my favorite a tool must meet the following criteria:

1. I use it every day because, once introduced, it has become an indispensable part of my life.
2. It has long-term potential. Some tools are cool and interesting but are not likely to go the distance.
3. It is at the center of my daily work flow. Some tools have a major impact on how everything is done.

The tool that is most indispensable, impactful, and future proof is Ubuntu 9.10. Every release has been incremental and more useful than the one before.

Most of my work life has been spent in front of a computer running some version of Microsoft Windows. But 2009 was the year that I escaped from Microsoft. Everything about how Windows works is intended to lock users in for the long-term. It is promoted as the "safe" computing platform and the only reasonable choice for users.

This year finally demonstrated the coming sea change. Open source providers are challenging entrenched monopolies on their home turf. Companies that rely mostly on the inability of their customers to switch are doomed to occupy a niche.

Linux is faster, more secure, and much lower maintenance cost than Windows. Forget that it is free. The cost of ownership totally dwarfs the initial fees to pay for the operating system. A typical computer user can expect to spend several hours a week administrating their computer. How much is 200 hours worth to you over the course of a year? Would you rather spend 50 hours instead?

I still use Windows when I have to, but I complain intensely about its failings. When I use a computer, it is expected to serve me. When I use Windows I expect to spend a large fraction of my time serving it instead. The biggest reason to use Windows is that you are already using Windows. How long is this situation sustainable? I believe that there is an open source revolution brewing.

Businesses and individuals have plenty incentive to move. When people feel that there is a safer more legitimate alternative, then they will make the switch. Once the flood begins it will not be held back.

This presents tremendous opportunity for people who can assist in making the move. Consider how you can be one of these people.
fields.title: Best in class operating system

fields.body:
Computers are great, but they can create new problems for you. After using computers for years, you can be buried in files. Learning how to harness these files, can make you much more effective, and also take a load off your mind.

An information management system allows you to guarantee that you will not loss information when your disk fails. You know it will eventually. It is one thing to have the information secure, but even better if you can find it when you need it. Following are a few tips that will help you manage computer files.

1. Make sure everything that you don't want to lose is backed up. This is best done by backing up your data files rather than your entire computer system. Your backup should be automatically run every day. Otherwise it will never be run.

2. Make sure that you have an off-site backup that is less than a month old.

3. Create an archive for each year. This lets you age older files off of your system while guaranteeing instant access to old projects. Synchronize your current working files into the archive regularly.

4. Every file should have one master copy. Don't duplicate directory trees with files. These will cause problems for you because you will not be able to remember which files are most recent.

There are other things that you can do, but these items are the first place to put your attention.
fields.title: Manage your information

fields.body:
We all know the pain of visiting a web site after a long time has elapsed only to find that we have forgotten the password. After reading this tip and applying it, you will never again forget a password.

Use KeePass to record all of your passwords. They are kept in an encrypted form in a database that is secure and yet easy to retrieve from. When KeePass starts you are prompted for the master password. Don't forget this and choose a high-quality password to protect this file.

KeePass allows you to define groups of passwords and records details and note associated with each of them. You can install KeePass on Windows, Linux or Mac. Another wonderful feature of this application is that the same database file can be opened on multiple operating systems. I synchronize the file accross multiple computers allows me to add and retrieve passwords from whichever computer I am using.

You can find out more information about this free application at http://KeePass.org.
fields.title: Manage your passwords in one place

fields.body:
I just got a new Droid phone.  It runs the Android operating system from Google.  It's like an open-source iPhone.  I absolutely love it.  In the past I used a WinCE Pocket PC phone, which works OK only if you live in the Microsoft world.

Right away, I was able to get the phone set up the way that I want.  After just 48 hours the phone has become an indispensable part of my personal productivity platform.  Here are the features that I really appreciate.

    * Open source platform means that I am not locked in to a single vendor that will squeeze money out of me each month.
    * Open source development is easy so there will be a large number of applications available for every purpose.  Who knows, I may just write something.
    * Five workspaces allow me to customize groups of tasks for my phone.
    * Automatically synchronizes my email, calendar, and task lists.  I can create stuff on my computer and it is fully accessible from anywhere.   It gives me the internet in my pocket.
    * Quick internet access at any time.
    * Beautiful and sharp display.

If you need a smart phone, consider a Droid.   I am glad I did.
fields.title: I love my Droid

fields.body:
Most modern households have a number of computers.  Each of these computers requires a minimum level of support.  Every computer should be backed up, preferably once a day.  Recently I put together a simple computer system to use as a home server for $200.  This article will walk you through this process so that you can set up your own home server.

There are a number of different options for how to configure the server.  The most important decision is the operating system that is run on the server.  My project goals are:

   1. to provide easy setup - it must be up and running in a weekend
   2. low cost - it should cost less than $500
   3. low maintenance - it needs to run headless in a closet without me thinking about it

This last goal forced me to choose Linux.   Windows machines require almost daily maintenance.  With Linux I am able to write simple scripts that accomplish everything that I need to do with the server.  Once developed, the script will not change automatically behind my back.  This gives me full control of how the server works.  Windows machines are notorious for magically breaking themselves while you sleep.

I started this project with a trip to Best Buy to find the cheapest computer that was fully assembled.  I found an Acer box the size of a Wii.  This tiny package sports a 1.6 GHz dual-core processor and 160GB disk for $200.  After cabling the computer it boots up into Windows XP.

The next step is to prepare a thumb drive so that it will install Linux.  To do this I use UNetBootin with the Ubuntu 8.04.  This gives me the latest version Linux with the Long-Term Support.  This is the best version to use with servers.  I originally tried to use the brand-new desktop version and ran into issues.

To install Linux from the thumb drive insert the thumb drive into a USB port and hit F12 while the computer boots.  This lets me boot off the live CD into Linux.  Next I get a choice about what I want to do.  It is a good idea to start by using the Live CD without installing to make sure that all of the drivers load properly.  Once you verify that these are all good you have confidence that the installed operating system will also work.

During the install you are prompted to define how the disk will be used.  I recommend using the entire disk.  Forget the previous operating system and start fresh.  Otherwise you will be dragging a boat anchor.  This is clearly your easiest alternative.

Answer the remaining questions and let the process chug away.  It will be done about 15 minutes later.  You now have a working Linux machine for $200 and an hour of invested time.
fields.title: Every home needs a server

fields.body:
Often people let their desktop fill up with many rows of icons.  The rationale is that having everything on the desktop makes it more accessible.  But the truth is that having a lot of icons on the desktop slows down completing tasks. It is a constant distraction of clutter.

The usefulness of any list is inversely proportional to its length.  A list of a hundred items is just noise that you have to ignore to do your work.  A small number of choices gives more efficiency to the task at hand.  The best rule-of-thumb is that each launcher icon should be a task that you are likely to require in the next hour.

The desktop is a great place to park items that are actively being worked on.  While switching from one task to the next, the items from the desktop should be stowed away. Items that are currently showing demand attention. Once they are dealt with they can be removed.

If your desktop is out of control then do this simple step.  Create a new folder on your desktop and drag all of your other icons into it.  When you need an icon you can simply open the folder and select it.  Any icon that you use more than three times in a day gets moved back to your desktop.  After a week remove the folder somewhere else slightly less convenient.  You will not end up placing more than five icons back on your desktop if you do this.

For the last few years I have maintained a clean desktop and recommend it to you.  It increases productivity and decreases the noise of mental clutter.  Try this simple improvement for one week and if it does not benefit you revert back to the current state.  It has not cost you any time.
fields.title: Clean up your desktop

fields.body:
We all know the pain of setting up a new computer system.  Even though people that work with computers all of the time have set up many computer systems in the past.  I regularly used about 7 different operating environments.  These differ by location, mobility, ownership, and purpose.
I now have a recipe that allows a new computer environment to start doing useful work in less than an hour.  Linux lends itself to this type of quick start.  I still find that setting up Windows systems is extremely time intensive.

First, Ubuntu is installed off of the Live CD.  This operation takes about 20 minutes with about 5 minutes of setup time and a break to watch a half-hour TV show.  When you return you are ready to customize the environment.   I have special commands that I am constantly updating.  Currently I have about 150 commands that automate everything that I do with the computer.   These commands are all stored in a directory called bin in my home directory.   They can be moved by network or thumb drive to any new system.

Next I link my script to customize the shell from my home directory using:
ln ~/bin/bashrc ~/.bashrc
Now you can make this active.
. ~/.bashrc

This process lets you get up and running in well less than an hour with a computer environment that has all of your favorite automation tools already configured.  Additional configuration can be done by including a “setup-computer” script in your bin directory.
fields.title: Quick cloning of computer environments

fields.body:
My main computer system does a dual-boot into either Ubuntu 9.10 or Windows 7. This lets me take advantage of the best features of each of these operating systems. Unfortunately, both of these operating systems have their own file system. This article will show you how to set up one set of documents that can be accessed from both operating systems.

The solution involves creating a tree of documents on the Windows system. I placed these in the default directory for Windows. On my system, the directory “c:\users\Mark\Documents\” holds the documents for the current user. So far, no special setup has been done.

Now for the trick. Mount the entire Windows file system by editing the /etc/fstab. This file system table controls which drives are mounted when the Linux system is booted. On my system I added the line:

/dev/sda1 /media/windows ntfs-3g nls=utf8,umask=077,uid=1000,gid=1000 01

sda1 is read as storage device A and partition 1. Check for your actual storage devices by listing /dev. Create a directory for this file system to occupy at “/media/windows”. To make this change active run “sudo mount /media/windows”. If this works you will have a bunch of files at /media/windows.

Now for the second trick. Create a symbolic link from your home folder to your windows file tree. Use the following command to do this:

ln -s /media/windows/users/documents ~/docs

Now the files in windows are readily accessible from your home directory at ~/docs. There is only one copy of each file so that you do not need to replicate anything. This is the perfect solution except for one issue the file system access through the Windows file system is much slower than accessing the files directly in the Linux file system. Otherwise I would consider doing the entire Linux system this way. However, this solution works extremely well for collections of documents that are regularly edited in both operating environments.
fields.title: Sharing files with dual boot

fields.body:
I had the remarkable chance to upgrade two operating systems in the same day. That gave me a unique opportunity to compare the features and the upgrade process of the two leading operating systems for the desktop. In both situation I had a previously installed version of the predecessor operating system installed on my hard disk.

The day began by tackling the Windows 7 install, which is touted as a “Simpler PC from day one”. I dual boot my machine into Windows or Linux. The Windows partition occupies 80 GB of space while the Linux partition uses 25 GB.

The Windows partition needs at least 12 GB free to attempt the install, so it took me three attempts to get the system to be content with the amount of space. By this point I had invested about three hours in the upgrade process.

Once I had enough space the install wizard automatically upgrades all of the files from my Windows Vista installation. This process took another 3 hours. After six hours I had a clean boot.

Windows 7 looks very attractive and also preserved my settings. I was able to run applications like Visual Studio without making any further adjustments.

The one unfortunate consequence of the Windows 7 install, is that it overwrote the boot partition. In order to fix this I decided to install the previous version of Linux on top of the existing partition. It was interesting to see that although it replaced all of the system files, it left my data files in place. The net result was to allow me to restore the operating system without destroying my data. I fully expected to have to recover my data from backups.

Once the Linux system was brought back to life, I had a system that would boot into either Windows 7 or Ubuntu 9.04. Next I was ready to tackle the Ubuntu upgrade, which was just released today. I was surprised to find that the Update Manager had a button to allow me to upgrade between major releases of the software.

Microsoft goes to great lengths to make sure that nobody steals Windows. This has a lot of negative consequences if you are trying to set up your system. I was told at the store where I bought Windows that if the shrink-wrap was removed that it would constitute being opened. That made me pause to consider whether I was really committed enough to get it to work, to account for the risk.

Instead of trying to make it hard to upgrade, the Linux creators where inviting me to click a button that would go get all of the files that had changed for the new release. Unfortunately, this is so inviting that I was probably one of a million people to attempt this activity on the day of the release. It determined that 1200 files were needed. The download is going very slowly but I am hoping that the invested time will be minimized.

Overall I am much more pleased with the way that Linux is upgraded and maintained than the heavy handed approach that Microsoft uses. Both operating systems have great functionality, but take much more effort to keep my Microsoft Windows machines running.
fields.title: Windows 7 vs. Ubuntu 9.10

fields.body:
In the mid-nineties creating a web site was extremely difficult. You needed to be a technical genius to use the tools that were available. Many people that became early adopters of the web are still locked into that mindset. Fortunately, the tools have improved considerably.

Today web sites are created so that you can update the content yourself. While it still may take somewhat of a genius to set it up, everyone can update the text within the structure of the site. In the middle of this decade we saw a number of tools released that allow you to maintain your own content. If you still rely on a web developer to add an upcoming event to your web site, then it is time for a change. A web site with obsolete material is a dead web site that no one will visit more than once.

My favorite tools for maintaining your own content are based on what you are trying to achieve with your site. For a blog, I believe the best tool is Word Press. For a basic web site that can act as a general technology platform, use Joomla. And for displaying photo galleries, check out Copper Mine Gallery. These three great tools can be used to offer state-of-the-art capability without requiring any programming.

Each of them have an administrator view that allows you to configure the options that you want. You may consider hiring a web developer that is familiar with these tools, if you want to save the time required to learn about them. The cost of hiring someone to set up these will be signicantly cheaper than the cost to build a traditional web site. But the biggest benefit of all, is that you can maintain your own content without having to pay someone else to do it for you.
fields.title: Update your own web site

fields.body:
A business portal can greatly simplify your life. Most businesses and organizations have a web site that is used to communicate outside of their organizations. Many fewer have a web site that is used to coordinate the work that happens within the organization. A Biz Portal is exactly that. It gives you an easy way to exchange information within the boundaries of the organization. It provides a focal point for all of the events, projects, news, and tools that each member might need to be successful.

A simple Biz Portal is easy to create, can be set up quickly, and enhanced as the needs grow. Your web site should offer the follow capabilities to your organization.

   1. Provide news for everyone to see
   2. Create a shared calendar where each person can post events
   3. Allow protected access from anywhere (with user passwords)
   4. Document repository for all of the instruction showing how to accomplish all tasks
   5. Project profiles and business plans (set up with controlled access for users)
   6. Task management tools to coordinate who does what
   7. Client information to provide access to key information

I recommend that a portal be implemented as a multi-page web site with the following main pages: Company, Marketing, Operations, Finance, and Clients. Within each of these pages are sections that can be selected with a secondary menu. These menus offer topics that are specific to each of the pages.

It is also a good idea to provide specific permissions for each individual that will use the site so that the correct information can be exposed. You may want to control who can see or edit what content. You will certainly want to limit all access to registered users. A system like this can typically be set up for a few hundred dollars.

If your organization's portal already does this, then breathe easy. If you would like more information on how to set this up for yourself, or would like Shrinking World Solutions to help you, then email me at Mark.Seaman@Shrinking-World.com
fields.title: Biz Portals make life easier

fields.body:
Have you ever had the following problem? You have a group of files that you move around between multiple computers. At each of these locations you may have edited some of the files. Suddenly, you realize that you are not sure where the most recent copy is kept. If this sounds familiar the SyncBack is your friend.

You can get SyncBack free from http://www.2brightsparks.com/downloads.html. This amazing application helps you solve the problem encountered with file replication. It is easy to set up and has many features that you can grow into over time. This article will cover the most basic use model.

You will most likely want to use SyncBack initially to synchronize files between two directories. To do this you create a profile and select the synchronize option. Then you specify the source and destination directories. When you run this profile the newer files that occur in one of the directories will be duplicated in the other. Files missing in either directory will be created in the other.

Here are four distinct ways that you can benefit from using SyncBack today.

   1. Thumb drive - Put files on a thumb drive and take them with you. Use synchronize to copy new files to your thumb drive, but also update your computer copies with edits that you made while you were away.
   2. Another hard disk - If you have a second hard disk you can synchronize directories between the two disks. This gives you a secondary copy if your computer crashes.
   3. Newtwork disk - If you have a LAN then it is easy to share a group of files between multiple users. Just set up the directories that you would like to replicate and everybody gets the updated files.
   4. FTP account - You can set up a directory to be synchronized to an FTP (File Transfer Protocol) account. No more fumbling with an FTP client application and figuring out which files to update.

Each of these use models produces real value for you. Pick the ones that you need and implement them today. You will want to adjust some of the options to more closely fit your specific needs. But this article should provide you with the motivation to get started.
fields.title: Synchronize your files

fields.body:
It is hard to pass up a bargain, especially when something is supposedly free. But in order to figure the real cost of something you must look at all of the factors. I often see people developing a web site in what appears to be a very low cost way, only to find out that the actual cost was many times what they thought. There are a lot of hidden cost in using technology. You must accurately figure these cost in or you will make some serious mistakes.

There are essentially three costs to developing a web site. These are the costs of learning new skills that you do not currently have, time spent doing the work, and dollars spent on professional services or tools. The latter is the cost that is obvious to most people. You know when you are about to purchase web site hosting or a web development tool, but the other costs might not be so obvious to you.

Most people believe that the time that it will take them to do the job is the time that it would take a fully trained professional. The reasoning is, “they are smart, but so am I”. If you read advertisements for tools, you see claims that you can achieve certain results in minutes. This may only be true after you have spent many hours learning the knowledge that you are missing.

It is true that any smart person can learn what is required to build a web site. The dirty little secret is that you may need to invest between 100 to 200 hours of your precious time discovering what you need to know. If you plan on building a number of different web sites then this is time well spent. Or if you feel that this is a hobby, you might gladly pay for the priviledge of learning. On the other hand, if this is just a job that you want done, it is difficult to justify the tremendous expense invovled.

Many people would not (and should not) embark on a project like this if they knew the actual costs. Unfortunately, the real costs become apparent only after you have invested the time. It is a little like buying an airplane only to find out that it will require another large investment to learn to fly it.

Here's the rule of thumb that I use when approaching new technology. I count the number of new tricks that need to be learned. This includes using a new editor, setting up the hosting environment, figuring out what a control panel is for, or configuring a blog. Anything that I do not have specific experience with goes on the list. Then multiply this number of items by four hours. You can learn a couple of new tricks in a day, but I'd bet money that you can't beat that on average.

Another assumption to make is that anything you have not seen running does not work. People assume that the technology should work. In reality, technology only works when you force it to. I've been building systems for 27 years and they only work because they are designed to.

All of these factors will help you get to the true cost of your web site project. What you don't know can truly hurt you, so it's best to do a careful assessment at the beginning of a project.
fields.title: Free can be really costly

fields.body:
There are seven key questions to answer before creating your web site:

   1. What business purpose must my web site serve?
   2. How do I measure success for this project?
   3. How much money should I invest in this site?
   4. How much time am I willing to invest?
   5. How quickly do I need the site completed?
   6. What other websites serve as examples to emulate?
   7. What priorities do I put on the following?  Cost, Time invested, Time to Completion, Functionality, Structure, Style,Features, Updates, Textual content, Interaction
fields.title: Before you create your web site

fields.body:
This is where the projects are won or lost. It is vital to establish with the customer (internal or external) what the desired outcome will be. This involves a common understanding of the following:

* What is the functionality and quality level of the work that is being produced

* Schedule for delivered results

* Options to customize the work as it is being developed

* Resources that will be required from the client in order to successfully complete the project

* Estimated cost of the project

* How to handle slippage (criteria of importance for cost, recourses, time, quality)

* Phased approach to limit risk and use results early

* Tracking methods to measure progress
fields.title: Setting expectations

fields.body:
When I first started Shrinking World Solutions I new that I needed a robust computing platform that could be used on every computer in the company. The heart of this computer strategy is the software used to run all of the functionality related to the office. The required functionality includes an email reader, word processing, presentations, and spreadsheets.

For many years I have used to Microsoft Office Suite to get all of this functionality with a single package. As I began to look at the cost of setting up this software on every computer in the company I realized that this could be quite expensive. I began to seriously consider the Open Office suite, for the first time.

Open Office is an Open Source alternative to Microsoft Office. It can be installed on your local computer free of charge. It is similar in many respects to the Microsoft software, but does it create compatibility problems. Over the years I have watched as coworkers have struggled to use tools that were different than what everyone else is using. My conclusion is that it is best to use mainstream software rather than cutting edge solutions.

I cautiously began to evaluate, and finally adopt, Open Office as a standard tool. It reads the Microsoft file formats and offers very similar functionality. It is easy to use and well-designed. The major disadvantage that it has is that it is different. There is always some amount of pain switching from one software application to another. I experienced a similar discomfort switching to the newer version of Microsoft Word.

My general recommendation is that Open Office provides a mainstream alternative to Microsoft Office. This is a great fit for a small company or organization that wishes to control costs. You can satisfy your business needs without spending any money per computer to do it. Like any new software you will need to think about how to overcome the initial learning curve.
fields.title: Using Open Office

fields.body:
During the development stage of the innovation cycle, you must try a lot of different things.   Find out what works and what fails.  Create a series of low-cost experiments to try several different ways of doing the same thing. 

The goal of this phase is to learn about the problem space not create the entire new solution.  Because you are trying a lot of new things you must keep each experiment very simple.  These experiments should be focused on those areas where you are lacking key pieces of information.
